Lack enough support: The claim of the global COVID-19 death toll exceeding 1.6 million does not provide any source or evidence to support this number.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the death toll from COVID-19 is accurately reported by governments, which may not always be the case.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the official COVID-19 death tolls reported by reliable sources such as Johns Hopkins University, the World Health Organization (WHO), and AFP.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim ignores the possibility of undercounting or discrepancies in the official death tolls due to various factors, such as unreported deaths or challenges in documenting COVID-19 fatalities.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the number of COVID-19 deaths by stating it as 1.6 million, which is significantly higher than the official figures.
Understate: There is no evidence to suggest that the claim understates the global COVID-19 death toll.
Falters at times: The claim falters by not providing a reliable source or evidence for the stated death toll and by contradicting official figures.
Alternative explanation: The claim does not provide an alternative explanation for the global COVID-19 death toll exceeding 1.6 million.
